Molybdenum catalyzed homogeneous hydrogenation reaction: Recent innovations in catalysts design, modes of activation and reaction mechanisms Shu-Fen Hou Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Project administration Investigation ⁎ Ailing Zhang Writing – review & editing Investigation Data curation Chunling Xin Writing – review & editing Mengyuan Zhang Writing – review & editing College of Chemical Engineering and Environmental Chemistry, Weifang University, Weifang 261061, China College of Chemical Engineering and Environmental Chemistry Weifang University Weifang 261061 China College of Chemical Engineering and Environmental Chemistry, Weifang University, Weifang 261061, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Transition metal-catalyzed reactions are increasingly recognized as essential in synthetic organic chemistry, due to their occurrence under relatively mild conditions. In this regard, molybdenum (Mo) complexes are considered as an attractive class of catalysts because of their rich redox activities, abundance and low toxicity. Molybdenum catalysis has seen significant advancements in recent years, leading to a diverse range of useful transformations for the activation of E-H bonds. Recent developments in Mo catalysis focusing on the hydrogenation reaction are highlighted in this perspective. Additionally, the synthesis of Mo-based catalysts and the reaction mechanism for hydrogenation are also discussed. Keywords Molybdenum catalysts Homogeneous hydrogenation reaction Synthesis of Mo compounds Ionic mechanisms Metal ligand cooperation mechanisms Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Molybdenum, ranked as the 54th most abundant element on Earth, is essential for nearly all organisms. It forms the catalytic center of numerous enzymes, including nitrogenase, formic acid dehydrogenase and carbon monoxide dehydrogenases (Scheme 1 ) [1,2]. As a transition metal, Mo is positioned between the early and late transition metals in periodic table of elements, typically exhibiting strong Lewis acidity and demonstrating high reactivity toward various organics [3–5]. Its low toxicity and distinct elemental properties make Mo both bioavailable and catalytically effective [6]. Mo-based compounds serve as efficient catalysts for several organic reactions, such as alkene metathesis [7–9], ammonia oxidation [10], epoxidation [11], nitrogen reduction [12–15] and hydrogenation reaction. Transition-metal complexes, recognized as excellent catalysts in hydrogenation, display specific characteristic reactivities in bond cleavage and formation [16,17]. Notably, Mo seems to have potential since it plays a vital role in the active centers of various redox-active enzymes [1] and is likewise inexpensive, environmentally benign, and furthermore, offers a rich coordination chemistry [18]. Significant advancements have been achieved with Mo in nitrogen activation and reduction [19,20]. Additionally, numerous innovations in catalyst design, reaction pathways, and activation modes have improved the efficiency and selectivity of molybdenum-catalyzed hydrogenation reactions. Chakraborty and co-workers have summarized group VI base metals (Cr, Mo and W) catalyzed homogeneous hydrogenation and dehydrogenation reactions [21]. Different from above, we particular focus on Mo-mediated homogeneous hydrogenation reaction. Except for homogeneous hydrogenation with H2 and transfer hydrogenation, hydroboration, hydrosilylation and hydrostannation reactions based on Mo are also included in this review. The homogenous hydrogenation reaction is categorized into five sections: hydrogenation with H2, transfer hydrogenation, hydroboration, hydrosilylation and hydrostannation. Each section was divided into sub-sections, according to the different substrates that have been hydrogenated. For instance, in the hydrogenation with H2 section, there are seven sub-sections, including ketones, imines, nitriles, amides, esters, alkenes, alkynes, N-heterocycles and arenes, hydrogenation. In each section, there is also a scheme showing the key Mo-complexes that will be described with the years they were published, the authors and the substrates they were used for. In each section, the reaction outcome, reaction mechanisms, and synthetic strategies for the Mo catalysts would also be included. 2 Hydrogenation with H2 Catalytic hydrogenation using H2 is recognized as both atom-economic and environmentally friendly. The first-row transition metals, particularly manganese, iron, and cobalt, have attracted considerable attention and achieved significant progress in hydrogenation reactions. In contrast, molybdenum has been less explored in hydrogenation catalysis. To date, a series of Mo-based compounds have been developed, demonstrating catalytic efficacy in the hydrogenation of ketones, imines, nitriles, amides, esters, alkenes, alkynes, N-heterocycles and arenes. Comprehensive mechanistic analyses have furthered understanding of the role of Group VI metals in activating hydrogen and facilitating its transfer to unsaturated organic compounds. The mechanisms of hydrogenation reactions with H2 catalyst by Mo were divided into two types of mechanisms: ionic hydrogenation mechanism and cooperation mechanism (Scheme 2 ). Ordinary, compounds such as Mo(CO)6, Mo(CO)5B−, and Mo compounds coordinated with Cp analogues and P-ligands follow an ionic hydrogenation mechanism. Metal hydride or metal-dihydride complexes serve as crucial intermediates during this process. The cooperation mechanism especially for metal–ligand cooperation is observed in Mo-pincer compounds, where hydrogen cleavage involves cooperation between Mo and N atoms, forming Mo-H and NH bonds [22]. Hydrogenation of ketones and aldehydes with H2. Alcohols result from the hydrogenation of ketones and aldehydes, primarily involving low-valent Mo0, MoI and MoII compounds (Scheme 3 ). The process typically proceeds via the ionic hydrogenation mechanism, involving oxidative addition of H2 followed by reductive elimination of the saturated alcohol products. The initial molybdenum-catalyzed hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds was first documented in 1985 by Markό et al. [23]. Utilizing commercial M(CO)6 (M = Cr, Mo, W) as the catalyst precursor, ketones were homogeneously hydrogenated to their respective alcohols in the presence of NaOMe or Et3N. The reaction occurred at 70 °C under a pressure of 98.67 atm (1450 psi) with M(CO)6 serving as the catalyst. Mo(CO)6 exhibited greater catalytic activity compared to similar carbonyl compounds of W and Cr. The mechanism was explored using Cr(CO)6, MeONa. During the process, MeOH worked as the solvent. Studies on stoichiometric reactions demonstrated the significant role of anionic metal carbonyl hydrides in the catalytic cycle. Then Darensbourg and co-workers reported the transformation of cyclohexanone to cyclohexanol using carboxylate anion complexes [M(CO)5(OAc)]– (M = Cr, Mo, W) as catalysts at 125 °C and 40.82 atm (600 psi) H2 pressure [24]. In this process, intermediates such as the anionic metal hydride HMo(CO)5 − and metal alkoxide compounds were proposed. In 2000, Bullock et al. reported molybdenum cationic compounds [CpMo(CO)2(PR3)]+ (R = Ph, Cy) Mo1 as catalyst precursors for the hydrogenation of 3-pentanone at 23 °C and less than 4 atm H2 [25]. Mo1 was formed by reacting CpMo(CO)2(PR3)H with the hydrogen abstraction reagent Ph3C+BAr’4 [Ar’ = 3, 5-bis(trifluoromethyl)phenyl]. Mechanistic studies revealed that the 16-electron organometallic cation Mo1 coordinated with ketones in an η 1 fashion. The cationic metal dihydride complex was generated from the reaction of Mo-ketones with H2. Proton was transferred from the acidic dihydride complex to the ketones yielded a neutral metal hydride complex and a protonated ketone. Subsequent the hydride was transferred to the protonated ketone, the CH bond was formed and alcohol was produced ultimately. Ketone coordination completed the catalytic cycle involving “Mo1” (Scheme 4 ). However, dissociation of the phosphine ligand led to catalyst decomposition, reducing the reaction conversion rate. To enhance catalyst lifetime, Morris et al. synthesized HMo(CO)[η 5:η 1-C5H4(CH2)nPR2] (n = 2 or 3; R = Ph, Cy, t Bu) Mo2, where the phosphine is tethered to the cyclopentadienyl ring by a hydrocarbon bridge [26,27]. Mo2 was synthesized in two steps: i) Reaction of Mo(CO)3(diglyme) with Li[C5H4(CH2)nPR2] produced the Li-salt Li{Mo(CO)3[η 5-C5H4(CH2)nPR2]}; ii) Protonation of the Li-salt with HOAc, releasing one CO yielded the Mo-H compound Mo2 (Scheme 5 ). Compared to unbridged Cp and PR3 systems, Mo2 systems exhibit lower catalyst loadings, higher thermal stability, and significantly longer lifetimes, although the catalytic efficiency of the complex is not markedly improved. Subsequently, Bullock’s group substituted the P-ligands of [MCp(CO)3-n(PR3)nH] systems with NHC-carbene ligands, resulting in inefficient catalysts for ketones hydrogenation due to the susceptibility of carbene ligands to protonation, forming imidazolium cations [28]. It was established that P-containing ligands are advantageous for ketone hydrogenation. Martins’s group replaced Cp or Cp* ligands with CpBz, based on the steric bulk of the Cp ligand and enhanced the catalytic activity [29,30]. Complexes featuring PNP pincer ligands have been highly effective in homogeneous hydrogenation reactions, including Mo-PNP complexes. Mo3, a Mo-PNP pincer complex, was synthesized using Mo(CO)6 as the starting material [31,32]. The synthesis proceeded through the following steps: (i) Heating Mo(CO)6 with 3-bromoprop-1-ene in mixture solutions of acetonitrile and benzene, produced [Mo(η 2-C3H5)(Br)(CH3CN)2(CO)2]. (ii) Addition of PPh3 generated Mo(PPh3)2(CO)2(CH3CN)2. (iii) Reaction of Mo(PPh3)2(CO)2(CH3CN)2 with the PNP pincer ligand ( i Pr2PCH2CH2)2NH in dichloromethane yielded Mo3 finally. Mo3 has demonstrated efficacy for hydrogenating of various para-substituted acetophenones, particularly in the presence of NaBHEt3 as an additive under 49.35 atm (50 bar) H2 (Scheme 6 ) [33]. Hydrogenation of amides with H2. In 2019, Beller et al. discovered that the compound Mo3 also catalyzed the hydrogenation of amides with high efficiency, yielding N-methylanilines and methanol from N-methylformanilides [34]. The reaction was conducted at 100 ℃ and 50 atm H2. Mechanistic studies indicated that the presence of methanol facilitated the protonolysis of the CN bond through the enhancement of OH deprotonation and N-protonation of the hemiaminal. The hydrogenation of amides involves a three-step process: reduction of the amide C = O, protonation of the CN bond in the formed hemiaminal, and reduction of the aldehyde CO (Scheme 7 ). The process initiates with the reduction of Mo3 by NaBHEt3 to form a Mo0-H compound, Mo3a. In Mo3a, metal–ligand cooperation facilitates the transfer of proton from the PNP ligand and a hydride from the metal center to the CO group in amides, forming intermediate Mo3b. In the presence of MeOH, N-atom protonation and CH3O– coordination to the Mo center occur, forming the Mo-alkoxo intermediate Mo3c. The proton from the hemiaminal intermediate transfers to the alkoxo group in Mo3c, forming Mo3d. Subsequently, the CN bond is cleaved; the proton in Mo3d transfers to the N atom, yielding N-methylanilines and formaldehyde. Under the catalysis of Mo3a, formaldehyde is hydrogenated to form methanol, and the catalyst Mo3a is regenerated by the reaction of Mo3c with hydrogen. Hydrogenation of esters with H2. Compared to complexes with P ligands, NHC ligands display unique electronic and steric benefits in transition metal catalysts. Recently, Beller’s group developed a series of Mo0 complexes with strongly electron-donating, bidentate NHC ligands. The synthesis of these compounds involved heating Mo(CO)3(CH3CN)3 with bis(NHC)-BEt3 adducts in toluene (Scheme 8 ). Particularly, the (NHC)Mo(CO)3(NCMe) compounds Mo4 exhibited high efficiency in the hydrogenation of various aliphatic and aromatic esters [35]. The stoichiometric reaction of Mo4 with t BuOK produced a mixture of Mo4a and Mo4b. The concurrent stoichiometric reaction of Mo4 with t BuOK and H2 yielded the hydride-bridged anion compound Mo4c. According to DFT calculations and stoichiometric reactions, the hydrogenation of esters followed an outer-sphere mechanism, rather than a metal–ligand cooperation mechanism. As depicted in Scheme 9 , substrates and H2 were activated by the Mo center. A mononuclear hydride Mo-H compound Mo4d was formed as an intermediate, equivalent to the binuclear hydride complex Mo4c. Under higher H2 pressures, Mo4d was the predominant product. The CO double bond in esters was inserted into the MoH bond in Mo4d, followed by cleavage of the CO single bond to yield aldehyde and alkoxy. Alcohol was produced in the presence of H2, and Mo4d was regenerated. Hydrogenation of imines and nitriles. The process of reacting imines and nitriles directly with H2 to produce their corresponding amines represents an atom-economic method. Initially, DuBois and colleagues described MoIV compounds with bridged-sulfur ligands Mo5 and Mo6 for hydrogenation of nitrogen-containing compounds (phenyl azide, imines and isothiocyanates). Post-2010, Berker’s group developed a series of molybdenum zero compounds utilizing diphosphines and tridentate pincer PNP ligands for the hydrogenation of various imines and nitriles (Scheme 10 ). The MoIV complexes [Cp’Mo(µ-S)2]S2CH2 Mo5 and [Cp’Mo(µ-S)(µ-SH)]2 Mo6 (Cp’ = CH3C5H4) exhibited catalytic activity in the hydrogenation of N-containing unsaturated compounds under 2–3 atm of hydrogen at room temperatures [36]. These complexes hydrogenated imines to the corresponding amines with a low TOF of 2, and the substrate scope was very limited. Studies on the mechanism demonstrated that sulfur ligands played a significant role in both hydrogen activation and the hydrogen transfer process. Then, a series of zero-valent [Mo(P-P)(CO)2(NO)H] compounds, Mo7, were synthesized by Berker’s group using diphosphine ligands (P-P = dippp, dippe, dippf, dcype) [37]. The zero-valent [Mo(NO)(CO)4(ClAlCl3)] served as excellent precursor, which afforded by the reaction of NOAlCl4 with Mo(CO)6 [38]. Combining [Mo(NO)(CO)4(ClAlCl3)] with diphosphine ligands yielded the chloride compounds [Mo(P-P)(CO)2(NO)Cl]. Mo7 were produced through a ligand exchange reaction of Mo chloride complexes with LiBH4 in Et3N at room temperature. In the presence of [H(Et2O)2][B(C6F5)4], a cationic complex Mo–THF was formed, exhibiting higher activity for imine hydrogenation, particularly showing a TOF of 123 h−1 towards hydrogenation of PhCH = N(α-naphthyl) when the diphosphane ligand was dippp (Scheme 11 ). The hydrogenation reaction was conducted at room temperature and 30 atm H2. In 2014, Berker’s group substituted the diphosphane ligands in Mo7 for a robust tridentate pincer phosphine ligand (PPP), resulting in the Mo0-H compound Mo8 [39]. This compound was synthesized using Mo(NCMe)2(NO)Cl3 as the starting material. The reaction of Mo(NCMe)2(NO)Cl3 with the PPP ligand produced the divalent Mo(PPP)(NO)Cl3. The reduction of this MoII compound in the presence of CO yielded the Mo0-Cl compound Mo(PPP)(NO)(CO)Cl. The coordinated Cl atom was abstracted by LiBH4 to finally afford Mo8 (Scheme 12 ). Mo8 demonstrated catalytic efficacy in the hydrogenation of various para-substituted imines to their corresponding amines in the presence of [H(Et2O)2][B(C6F5)4]. The maximal initial TOF was achieved 1960 h−1 under 59.22 atm (60 bar) H2 at 140 °C. It was established that the hydrogenation followed an ionic hydrogenation mechanism (Scheme 13 ), involving heterolytic splitting of H2 into proton and hydride, with the proton transferring to the N atom and the hydride to the C atom in imines. The activation of H2 was identified as the rate-determining step. In the same year, Berker et al. extended their prior work on the bifunctional hydrogenation of imines by amide complexes of the type [M(NO)(CO)(PNP)]. The complex [Mo(NO)(CO)4(ClAlCl3)] was heated with ( i Pr2PCH2CH2)2NH (PN H P), resulting in the formation of [Mo(NO)(CO)(PN H P)Cl] complexes. In the presence of the amide base Na[(SiMe3)2], the H atom in the PN H P ligand moieties and the Cl atom were abstracted, leading to the formation of the dehydrochlorination compound [Mo(NO)(CO)(PNP)] (PNP = ( i Pr2PCH2CH2)2N) Mo9, which catalyzed the hydrogenation of imine to N-benzylideneaniline under 59.22 atm (60 bar) H2 at 140 °C (Scheme 14 ) [40]. Contrary to the ionic hydrogenations, the hydrogenation of imines via the “Mo-N H ” cooperation was occurred. These amido complexes Mo9 cleaved dihydrogen in a heterolytic manner across the polar MN double bond to produce hydride-amine complexes Mo9a through a formal 1,2-addition. The Mo-H hydride was transferred to C atoms and N–H proton to N atoms of imines (Scheme 15 ). The reaction rate was influenced by the catalyst concentration and hydrogen pressure. Beller and associates also discovered that the compound Mo9 served as an active catalyst for the hydrogenation of nitriles to N-substituted imines without additives (Scheme 16 ) [41]. The conversion of the reaction was upto 99 %, and selectivity was upto 96 %. The N-substituted imines were formed by primary amines attacking the intermediate imines, leading to the production of gem-diamines, which were subsequently expelled to release NH3. This marked the first example of Mo-based catalysts being used for the hydrogenation of nitriles. Moreover, Beker and co-workers reported a (PNP)Mo(CO)2NCMe compound Mo10, which catalyzed the conversion of nitriles to primary amines [42]. The catalytic process was carried out at 100 °C and 49.35 atm (50 bar) H2 in the presence of NaBHEt3. Unlike other PNP Mo catalysts, treatment of Mo10 with two equivalents of NaBHEt3 involved deprotonation not at the NH moiety of the pincer ligand but at the CH3-group of the coordinated acetonitrile ligand, resulting in the formation of a covalent CB bond Mo10a (Scheme 17 ). Hydrogenation of alkenes and alkynes with H2. The olefin hydrogenation catalysts utilizing Mo0, MoI and MoII have been developed (Scheme 18 ). Frankel et al. developed Mo0 tricarbonyl compounds Mo11 for selectively hydrogenating conjugated olefins, and highlighted their effectiveness in hydrogenating the CC bond in methyl sorbate [43]. In 2009, Baricelli and co-workers reported on the Mo0 complex Mo(CO)3(NCMe)(PPh3)2 (Mo12), which catalyzed the conversion of simple alkenes to their corresponding saturated alkanes under conditions of 100 °C and 60 atm H2 [44]. Mo12 was synthesized by heating Mo(CO)3(NCMe)3 with two equivalents of PPh3 in acetonitrile. Importantly, the catalyst’s performance was unaffected by the presence of dibenzothiophene or mercury. Berker and colleagues described trisphosphine-chelated molybdenum nitrosyl hydride complexes Mo13, used for olefin hydrogenation in the presence of hydrosilane/B(C6F5)3 [39]. Mo13 was synthesized via several steps (Scheme 19 ): initially, reacting [Mo(NO)Cl3(NCMe)2] with the trisphosphine ligand ( i Pr2PCH2CH2)2PPh formed MoII complexes Mo(PPP)(NO)Cl3. These were then reduced with Na/Hg in the presence of ethylene to yield the Mo-ethylene intermediate. Finally, the reduction of the Mo-ethylene intermediates with NaBHEt3 or LiBH4 resulted in Mo13. The co-catalyst hydrosilane/B(C6F5)3 facilitated NO bond bending and created vacant sites for olefin interaction. Mo3 was also demonstrated efficacy as a well-defined catalyst for hydrogenating styrene, particularly in the presence of NaBHEt3 as an additive under 49.35 atm (50 bar) H2 (Scheme 20 ) [33]. In 2018, Chirk and co-workers disclosed Mo14, a bis(alkyl) molybdenum complex, (4- t Bu- i PrPDI)Mo(CH2SiMe3)2, noted for its effective catalytic activity towards various olefins under 4 atm H2 at 23 °C [45]. The complex was prepared by initially heating MoCl3(THF)3 with the PDI-ligand in toluene to yield (4- t Bu- i PrPDI)MoCl3 [46]. Mo14 was synthesized through the reduction of (4- t Bu- i PrPDI)MoCl3 with neosilyllithium, as outlined in Scheme 21 . Recently, Wang’s group reported Mo15, a cationic MoII-vinylthioether complex [Cp*Mo(1,2-Ph2PC6H4SCH = CH2)(Py)]BArF 4, which displayed effective catalytic activity for hydrogenation of various aromatic and aliphatic alkenes without any additives under room temperature and 1 atm H2 [47]. Mo15 was synthesized through the following steps: (i) Exchange of coordinated MeCN in [Cp*Mo(1,2-Ph2PC6H4S)(η 2-NCMe)] Mo15a with acetylene to form the acetylene compound Mo15b. (ii) Protonation of Mo15b with the pyridinium salt [C5H5NH]BArF 4 (where BArF 4 = (3,5-(CF3)2C6H3)4B) facilitated reductive coupling of the vinyl ligand and the thiolate, resulting in Mo15 (Scheme 22 ). The hydrogenation of olefins catalyzed by Mo15 via an ionic mechanism, involving the oxidative addition of hydrogen to the cationic MoII center to generate the MoIV dihydride intermediate Mo15-H2. Semi-hydrogenation of alkynes with H2. Semi-hydrogenation of alkynes poses significant challenges, especially when hydrogen is used as the hydrogen source, due to the complexities in controlling stereo- ((Z)/(E)-isomers) and chemoselectivity (alkanes vs alkenes). Beller and co-workers employed Mo16 as a catalyst for this process, achieving favorable stereoselectivity and chemoselectivity (Scheme 23 ) [48]. The predominant hydrogenated products are (Z)-alkenes. Mo16 was synthesized by directly reacting Mo(CH3CN)2(CO)2(PPh3)2 with a PNP-ligand. However, this catalytic system shows limited tolerance towards substrates with electron-withdrawing substituents. The reaction proceeds via an outer-sphere mechanism involving “Mo-N H ” cooperation. Hydrogenation of N-heterocycles and arenes. Group 6 metals in low oxidation states are commonly employed for activating arenes, valued for their arenophilicity and reliable performance (Scheme 24 ) [49–51]. Aromatic rings can coordinate to metal center via various models including η 2, η 4, η 6 and η 7. Parkin and co-workers have developed the (Me3P)4MoH4 as a catalyst for the hydrogenation of nitrogen heterocyclic ring compounds, achieving moderate yields [52]. The hydrogenation reaction was conducted at 100 °C and 78.95 atm (80 bar) H2 over several days. In this process, heterocyclics were coordinated to Mo by N-heterocyclic in a η 6-manner (Scheme 25 ) [52]. Chirik and associates observed that Mo14 could catalyze not only the hydrogenation of olefins but also the hydrogenation of aromatic rings such as toluene, o-xylene, and naphthalene at 3.95 atm (4 bar) H2 [45]. Notably, in naphthalene, only one of the rings was hydrogenated. Harsh reaction conditions were required for the hydrogenation of other sterically hindered substrates. Following these findings, Chirik’s group modified the pincer ligand of Mo14 with chiral substituents to produce the [(4- t Bu-tBuOIP)Mo(COD)] (OIP = oxazoline(imino)pyridine) complex, Mo17, for the asymmetric hydrogenation of quinolines and naphthalene derivatives [53]. They achieved the hydrogenation of various substituted naphthalenes and quinolones, resulting in enantioenriched decalins or tetrahydroquinolines with high diastereo- and enantioselectivities at 78.95 atm (80 bar) H2 and 80 °C. During the hydrogenation, Mo-η 6-arene compounds served as the resting states. To explore the mechanism of arene hydrogenation catalyzed by Mo-pincer compounds, Chirik and co-workers recently synthesized a series of phosphino(imino)pyridine (PIP) molybdenum complexes, Mo18 [54]. These compounds were synthesized in two steps (Scheme 26 ): (i) heating the PIP-ligand with MoCl3(THF)3 produced (PIP)MoCl3; (ii) The reduction of (PIP)MoCl3 with Na/Hg in the presence of excess 1,5-cyclooctadiene led to the formation of Mo18. When Mo18 was exposed to hydrogen in a benzene solution, it formed molybdenum cyclohexadienyl hydrides [(PIP)MoH(η 5-C6H7)] compound, indicating that benzene was inserted into a molybdenum hydride bond, a key step in the arene hydrogenation process (Scheme 27 ). As pre-catalysts, Mo18 provided a TON of 56 and exhibited higher activity than Mo14 (TON = 19 at 23 °C) in arene hydrogenation. 3 Transfer hydrogenation Due to the mild conditions, transfer hydrogenation reactions are favored by scientists for investigating the reaction mechanism [55,56]. Concurrently, extensive studies have explored the mechanisms of hydrogenation [57]. Both hydrogenation and transfer hydrogenation are direct methods for obtaining various hydrogenated compounds [58]. In contrast to hydrogenation, transfer hydrogenation involves adding H+ and H− to unsaturated organics using non-hydrogen donors. Common H donors in transfer hydrogenation includes alcohols, formic acid, and amines. During transfer hydrogenation, Mo-based catalysts typically interact with H donors to form Mo-H compounds, widely recognized as active intermediates in catalytic reactions. Commonly used molybdenum catalysts for transfer hydrogenation include Mo0, MoII and MoIV compounds (Scheme 28 ). In 1977, Tominaga et al. published findings on the transfer hydrogenation of cyclohexanone to cyclohexanol using a zero-valent molybdenum complex chelated with the bisphosphine ligand Mo19 [59]. This reaction employed 1-phenylethanol or 2-isopropyl alcohol as hydrogen donors and conducted at 80 °C. Interaction of Mo19 with these H donors produced Mo(DPE)2H4 (DPE = 1, 2-bis(diphenylphoshino)ethane ) as an intermediate. Tyler et al. have explored the aqueous chemistry of molybdenocene catalysts for the transfer hydrogenation of ketones, utilizing isopropyl alcohol as the hydrogen donors [60,61]. Kuo and Tayler utilized the MoIV compounds Cp R 2Mo(µ-OH)2MoCp R 2](OTs)2 (R = Me, Mo20; R = H, Mo21) as a catalyst and 2-propanol as the hydrogen donors for the hydrogenation of acetophenone [62]. During this process, molybdocene hydride served as the pivotal intermediate. In 2015, Parkin et al. showed that the divalent cyclopentadienyl molybdenum hydride compound CpMo(CO)3H (Mo22) acts as a catalyst in the transfer hydrogenation of a wide range of carbonyl compounds with HCOOH [63]. This process involves the simultaneous decarboxylation and disproportionation of formic acid (Scheme 29 ). In 2018, Waymouth et al. reported the transfer hydrogenation of aldehydes, ketones, and imines using the tetraphenylcyclopentadienone complex (C5Ph4O)Mo(CO)3(CH3CN) (Mo23) as a precursor under mild conditions, utilizing either 2-propanol or formic acid as hydrogen donors [64]. The precursor Mo(CO)3(NCMe)3 was obtained through the heating of Mo(CO)6 in acetonitrile [65]. Treatment of Mo23 with 2-propanol resulted in the formation of Mo-H (C5Ph4OH)Mo(H)(CO)3 compound Mo23b, identified as the effective catalyst for the reaction (Scheme 30 ). In 1H NMR spectroscopy, the hydride chemical shift was detected at −3.92 ppm. Similar chemical shift were observed during kinetic studies, confirming the active role of the Mo-H compound as an intermediate in the catalytic process. In 2020, Wang et al. synthesized the MoII acetonitrile compound Mo 15a where acetonitrile coordinated to Mo through a carbon–nitrogen triple bond [66]. Mo15a efficiently catalyzed the transfer hydrogenation of nitriles with ammonia borane (H3N·BH3) as the H source donor at ambient temperature, yielding primary amines. The synthesis steps are outlined as follows (Scheme 31 ): Cp*Mo(CO)3Cl reacted with the P-S ligand (P-S = 1,2-Ph2PC6H4S−) to eliminate NaCl and CO, producing Cp*Mo(1,2-Ph2PC6H4S)(CO)2. Oxidation of Cp*Mo(1,2-Ph2PC6H4S)(CO)2 led to decarbonylation and the formation of the MoIV compound [Cp*Mo(1,2-Ph2PC6H4S)(NCMe)3]2+. In the MoIV complex, acetonitrile and the metal center coordinated via the lone pair electron of nitrogen. Reduction of this complex yielded the bivalent molybdenum complex Cp*Mo(1,2-Ph2PC6H4S)(η 2-NCMe) Mo15a. Similar to Waymouth’s catalyst, the stoichiometric reaction of Mo15a with H3N·BH3 produced a MoII-H compound. The solid-state structure of MoII-H compound indicated cleavage of the BH bond in H3N·BH3 into BH2 and Mo-H parts through Mo-S cooperation. Kinetic analysis of the transfer hydrogenation revealed first-order kinetics in catalyst and H3N·BH3, and zero-order kinetics in the substrate. Using isotopically labeled D3N·BH3 and H3N·BD3 as hydrogen sources showed that the H atoms of NH3 in amine borane transferred to the N atom in the CN bond, while the H atoms of BH3 transferred to the C atom, consistent with DFT calculations. The mechanism is shown in Scheme 32 . The N-N ligand was employed to synthesize a series of Mo0 and MoI compounds (N-N ligands = N1, N1-dialkyl-N2-(5,6,7,8-tetrahydroquinolin-8-yl)ethane-1,2-diamines) by reacting with Mo(CO)6 or other Mo precursors like Mo(η 3-C3H5)(CO)2(CH3CN)2Br and Mo(PPh3)2(CO)2(CH3CN)2 [67]. It was found that Mo(N-N)(CO)2Br(η 3-C3H5) Mo24 was highly effective for the transfer hydrogenation of various aryl and alkyl ketones with i PrOH (Scheme 33 ). 4 Hydroboration Just like hydrogenation, hydroboration entails adding a boron–hydrogen bond to an unsaturated organic group. This process yields organoboranes, which are versatile intermediates capable of being transformed into various functional groups [68]. However, there have been few reports on the catalytic hydroboration of unsaturated compounds by molybdenum (Scheme 34 ). Hydroboration of nitriles. In 2012, Nikonov et al. reported on MoIV imido-hydrido complex (ArN)Mo(H)(Cl)(PMe3)3 (Mo25), which displayed activity towards various organic substrates such as ketones, esters, alkenes, and alkynes, yielding their respective hydroboration products [69]. Mo25 was synthesized by three steps (Scheme 35 ): initially, [Mo(NAr)2Cl2(dme)] was reduced in the presence of PMe3 and KC8 to form [Mo(NAr)2(PMe3)3] [70], subsequent reaction with excess HSiClMe2 produced [Mo(NAr)Cl2(PMe3)3] [71]. Finally, (ArN)Mo(H)(Cl)(PMe3)3 was obtained by reacting [Mo(NAr)Cl2(PMe3)3] with L-selectride [72]. Mo25 is highly effective in the hydroboration of nitriles with HBCat (Catecholborane), leading to the formation of bis(borylated) amines RCH2N(BCat)2 [73]. According to the nitriles hydroboration mechanism, Mo25 reacts with HBCat to release PMe3·BHCat, forming the coordinatively unsaturated Mo imido-hydrido complex Mo25a. The triple bond of the nitrile C≡N inserts into the Mo-H bond, resulting in Mo25b. Subsequently, HBcat incorporates into the Mo-N structural unit, forming the amido-borane mixture Mo25c. The BH bond then cleaves to form κ1-(N-borane) imine complex Mo25d. Finally, Mo25e coordinates the CN double bond in an ƞ 2 fashion, leading to the formation of PhCH2N(BCat)2 with another HBCat (Scheme 36 ). Hydroboration of CO2. Trovitch et al. synthesized a series of is(imino)pyridine or pyridine diamine (PDI) molybdenum complexes [74]. Oxidation of Mo0 (Ph2PPrPDI)Mo(CO) with I2 resulted in the formation of the seven-coordinate MoII complex [(Ph2PPrPDI)MoI(CO)] [I]. Heating the MoII complex under vacuum led to the release of coordinated CO. Reduction of the MoII compound with K-Hg activated an intramolecular CH bond in the ligand, producing the Mo0-H compound Mo26 (Scheme 37 ). Mo26 functioned as a catalyst for CO2 reduction in the presence of HBPin (Pinacol Borane), leading to the specific production of H3COBPin and O(BPin)2. CO2 was incorporated into the Mo-H catalyst to form (κ6-P,N,N,N,C,P-Ph2PPrPDI)Mo(OCOH). The proposed mechanism for the Mo26-mediated CO2 hydroboration involves a sequence of σ-bond metathesis and insertion processes (Scheme 38 ). 5 Hydrosilylation Mo-based catalysts for the hydrosilylation of unsaturated compounds fall into three categories: high-valent Mo = O compounds, MoIV = N compounds and low-valent Mo-P compounds (Scheme 39 ). Mo-oxo complexes have introduced a wide range of new catalysts and reaction mechanisms. Enzymes with an active [MoO2]2+ center exhibit reversible activity, functioning in both oxidative and reductive roles in biological contexts. Aldehyde oxidoreductase enzymes illustrate this versatility, utilizing [MoO2]2+ centers to catalyze the oxidation of aldehydes to carboxylic acids and the reduction of aldehydes to alcohols [75]. Hydrosilylation of aldehydes and ketones by Mo-oxo complexes. The high-valent Mo = O compound [MoVICl2O2] has been demonstrated to catalyze the addition of PhSiMe2H to aldehydes and ketones, yielding the corresponding dimethylphenylsilyl ethers in quantitative yield [76], as well as the reduction of imines to amines using PhSiH3 [77]. As depicted by the stoichiometric reaction of [MoCl2O2] with silane and DFT calculation [78], the author proposed there pathways of hydrosilylation: concerted addition, classical hydride migration, and radical reaction(Scheme 40 and scheme 41 ). Either way, the SiH bond in silane undergoes a [2 + 2]-addition to the MoO bond firstly. In the [MoCl2O2]/NCMe system, the radical path is probably the most likely if the experimental data is considered (Scheme 41). This addition is followed by a homolytic Mo–H cleavage that produces a H radical. The transfer of this H radical from the metal to the carbonyl group leads to the creation of an alkoxyl radical, which then combines with the Mo center. Ultimately, the silyl group −SiR3 transfers to the alkoxide, forming the silyl ether. Apart from [MoCl2O2], Royo et al. identified other dioxomolybdenum(VI) complexes such as [MoO2(acac)2], [CpMoO2Cl] and [MoO2(mes)2] that were activated for the hydrosilylation of aldehydes and ketones with Ph2SiH2. Among these, [MoO2Cl2] was identified as the most efficient catalyst [79,80]. In 2009, Abu-Omar et al. synthesized several MoVI dioxo salalen complexes that functioned as catalysts for the hydrosilylation of aldehydes and ketones with PhSiH3 [81]. Nikonov et al. synthesized an agostic silylamido complex, Mo27, that catalyzed the reaction of benzaldehyde with PhSiH3, achieving 100 % conversion of benzaldehyde after 16 h [82]. Two equivalents of PhSiH3 reacted with the bis(imido) compound (Ar’N)2Mo(PMe3)3 (Ar’ = 2, 6-diisopropylphenyl) to yield the β-agostic NSiH···Mo complex Mo27, a product of double silane addition (Scheme 42 ). However, Mo27 was found to be inactive in the hydrosilylation of alkenes and alkynes. It was established that the stability of Mo catalysts during catalysis was enhanced by the coordination of the P-ligand. Nikonov et al. also discovered that the MoIV imido complex Mo25 not only catalyzes hydroboration of unsaturated bonds but also catalyzes carbonyl hydrosilylation [72]. Contrary to previous findings, Mo25 initially reacted with benzaldehyde rather than silanes. The reaction of Mo25 with benzaldehyde resulted in η 2-coordination to form the PhC(O)H complex Mo25b. In the presence of PMe3, Mo25b transformed into an oxygen atom coordination complex Mo25c. Upon the elimination of PMe3, silane reacted with Mo25d, producing PhH2C-OSiH2Ph and regenerating the Mo hydride compound Mo25a (Scheme 43 ). Nevertheless, the exact mechanism of silane activation, whether through Si-H addition to form a MoVI complex or through σ-bond metathesis, remains to be clarified. Berker et al. reported a low-valent molybdenum diphosphine compound [Mo(NO)(P-P)(NCMe)3]+[BArF 4]−, (P-P = DPEphos = (Ph2PC6H4)2O), designated as Mo28, catalyzed the hydrosilylation of ketones and aldehydes with PhMeSiH2 [83]. This catalyst was synthesized from Mo(NO)Cl3(NCMe)2 in three steps (Scheme 44 ): First, Mo(NO)Cl3(NCMe)2 reacted with the P-P ligand (P-P = DPEphos = (Ph2PC6H4)2O) to yield the dinuclear species [Mo(NO)(P-P)Cl2]2[µ-Cl]2. Subsequent reduction of this species with Zn and then replacement of the counteranion produced Mo28. The hydrosilylation reaction was carried out using PhMeSiH2 as the Si-H source, various ketones and aldehydes as substrates, and low-valent [Mo(NO)(P-P)(NCMe)3]+[BArF 4]− as the catalyst at 120 °C over 3 h. The mechanism was investigated through kinetic studies, Hammett correlation study, and deuterium labeling study. Catalytic intermediates were formed by the reaction of the catalyst with excess ketones and characterized with 31P NMR spectra. When the author mixed Mo28 with 25 equiv. of acetophenone, the 31P NMR spectra showed appearance of a new singlet signal. The new signal was attributed to the formation of a ketone species of type [Mo(NO)(P-P)(η 1-OCPhMe)(NCMe)2]+[BArF 4]−.The proposed mechanism, outlined in Scheme 45 , involves the replacement of the coordinated acetonitrile by ketones or aldehydes, followed by the oxidative addition of silane to the Mo center to form a Mo-H compound. Finally, the hydride and silyl groups are transferred to the CO double bond of the substrates, with the concomitant reductive elimination of silyl ethers. In contrast, in 2014, Trovitch’s group [84] reported a zero-valence Mo compound, (Ph2PPrPDI)Mo(CO) (Mo29), for the hydrosilylation of aldehydes with PhSiH3 at 90 °C (Scheme 46 ). Mo29 was synthesized by heating Mo(CO)6 with a P-containing ligand at 120 °C. Unlike the mechanism proposed by Berker, Trovitch’s group suggested the insertion of substrates into the MoH bond, rather than a hydride transfer process. Due to the presence of the coordinated CO ligand, Mo29 is less reactive than Mo28. 6 Hydrostannation The hydrostannation reaction represents another significant type of reaction catalyzed by Mo complexes, particularly for the hydrostannation of alkynes. Molybdenum carbonyl compounds exhibit good reactivity and regioselectivities in hydrostannation of alkynes reactions (Scheme 47 ) [85–90]. As a commercially available material, Mo(CO)6 displays moderate yields and selectivity for alkyne hydrostannation due to the strong coordination of CO. However, replacing the coordinated CO ligand with isoelectronic isonitriles in the presence of catalytic amounts of CoCl2 results in the formation of zero-valent isocyanide carbonyl compounds Mo(CO)x(NC t R)6-x [91]. This modified compound, compared to Mo(CO)6, demonstrates improved reactivity and regioselectivities for the hydrostannation of alkynes, especially Mo(CO)3(NC t Bu)3 [62]. The isonitriles are bound more weaker to the Mo center compared with CO ligands, due to the weaker p-back donation from the metal to the isonitrile. Consequently, they can dissociate rapidly, allowing the catalytically active metal to access vacant coordination sites. After the reaction, the isonitrile remains in solution and can re-coordinate with the metal, ultimately regenerating the catalyst. It has been demonstrated that Mo(CO)3(NC t Bu)3 acts as a suitable catalyst for the regioselective hydrostannation of various alkynes, such as propargylic esters or protected propargyl alcohols, producing α-stannylated products with outstanding selectivity and yield [85]. Furthermore, the hydrostannation reaction is influenced by the steric and electronic properties of the isonitrile [86]. Kazmaier and co-workers have studied the influence of isonitrile ligands on the regioselectivity of the hydrostannation. As it is shown in Table 1. , the number of coordinated isonitriles in Mo(CO)x(NCtR)6-x would impacts the yield or selectivity of the reaction. Substitution of CO ligands in Mo(CO)6 by isonitrile ligands resulted in increase in the yield and the selectivity. The best result was obtained with Mo(CO)3(CN t Bu)3 (entry 4). While substitution of CO ligands in Mo(CO)3(CN t Bu)3 by the isonitrile ligands resulted in decrease in the yield and the selectivity (entry 5). Compared to tungsten analogues, Mo(CO)3(NC t Bu)3 continues to be one of the most effective hydrostannation catalysts, exhibiting excellent yields and regioselectivity with a variety of propargylic substrates for α-products [88]. According to experimental observations, Kazmaier et al. proposed a mechanism for the hydrostannation of alkynes involving different products and various catalysts (Scheme 48 ). The reaction initiates as two isonitrile ligands dissociate from the catalyst, allowing Bu3SnH to react with the unsaturated compound via oxidative addition, resulting in the formation of the M−Sn−H complex (A). The alkyne then coordinates to the metal in a side-on mode (B), and the subsequent insertion of the alkyne into the MSn bond generates complex (C). For catalysts with isonitrile ligands, the dissociated isonitriles remain in the solution, and upon re-coordination of isonitrile, a reductive elimination reaction occurs, forming α-products and regenerating the catalyst. In 2018, Figueroa et al. replaced the t Bu ligand in t BuNC with the more sterically encumbered ligand ArDipp2 (ArDipp2 = 2,6-(2,6-( i Pr)2C6H3)2C6H3), afforded divalent molybdenum iodide compound MoI2(CO)2(CNArDipp2)2 Mo30. This compound catalyzed the hydrostannation of both terminal and internal alkynes with HSn n Bu3 to yield β-stannylated rather than α-stannylated products [90]. The authors speculated that Mo30 is reduced by HSn n Bu3 to form a 14-electron zero-valent molybdenum complex, Mo(CO)4(CNArDipp2)2 (Mo30a), which acts as an active intermediate. Further, HSn n Bu3 reacts with Mo30a via oxidative addition, resulting in the formation of the Mo-H compound Mo30b. To verify this speculation, the authors introduced HN i Pr2 into the reaction system, obtaining the zero-valent molybdenum complex Mo30d (Scheme 49 ). 7 Conclusion and Future outlook In general, Mo complexes have been effectively utilized as hydrogenation catalysts, although their use has been somewhat less attractive due to the relatively harsh reaction conditions and higher metal loadings compared to well-established first-row transition metal catalysts. As it was showed in scheme 50 , Mo-pincer compound (Mo16) [42] and the first-row transition metal pincer catalysts (Mn [92], Fe [93] and Co [94]) have worked as the catalysts for nitriles reduction. Compared Mo catalyst with Fe and Co catalysts, the reaction required more catalyst loading, higher hydrogen pressure and more additive loading. Compared Mo catalyst with Mn catalyst, Mo metal catalyst was needed more catalyst loading. Although the Mn catalyst has a slightly higher temperature, it maybe due to the replacing NaBHEt3 with t-BuONa. This review has highlighted the synthesis and application of molybdenum-based hydrogenation reactions. From a structural perspective, various molybdenum complexes with “PPP”, “NNN”, “PNP” pincer ligands have been well-developed for hydrogenation reactions. Additionally, molybdenum complexes chelated with Cp or Cp analogs have also demonstrated effective reactivities in hydrogenation with H2 and transfer hydrogenation reactions. Notably, Mo-imido complexes have shown specific activation for unsaturated bonds, Si-H, and B-H bonds. From the perspective of mechanism, hydrogenation with H2 involves two primary mechanisms: the ionic mechanism and the metal–ligand cooperation mechanism. In the ionic mechanism, H2 reacts with Mo catalysts to yield Mo dihydride complexes, while the metal–ligand cooperation often involves “Mo-N” interactions. For transfer hydrogenation, hydroboration, hydrosilylation, and hydrostannation, the activation of the E-H bond is a crucial step. This activation typically occurs via oxidative addition or through “Mo-N” and “Mo-S” cooperation. However, the development of novel synthetic strategies to access unsaturated molybdenum complexes is critical for expanding reactivity studies, which will be of particular interest in Mo-based catalysis research. Most Mo catalysts are derived from Mo carbonyl complexes; carbonyl is a strong field ligand, which restricts the reaction activity of molybdenum compounds. To date, methods to dissociate molybdenum and CO include heating, oxidation reactions, or photoactivation. Moreover, considering the structural characteristics of molybdenum-containing enzymes, catalytic conversion of organic compounds can also be achieved using a multi-metal coordination strategy. This approach provides a new avenue for the development of molybdenum-based catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Transition metal-catalyzed reactions are increasingly recognized as essential in synthetic organic chemistry, due to their occurrence under relatively mild conditions. In this regard, molybdenum (Mo) complexes are considered as an attractive class of catalysts because of their rich redox activities, abundance and low toxicity. Molybdenum catalysis has seen significant advancements in recent years, leading to a diverse range of useful transformations for the activation of E-H bonds. Recent developments in Mo catalysis focusing on the hydrogenation reaction are highlighted in this perspective. Additionally, the synthesis of Mo-based catalysts and the reaction mechanism for hydrogenation are also discussed.
